docs.snippet: Sunday was a big night for awards, but not for Oscar clarity....
docs.lead_paragraph: There was a lot to stare at yesterday. The BAFTA's, the Writers Guild, the animation awards, the Grammy's. Well, O.K., the Grammy's didn't have much to do with anything, unless the Dixie Chicks's big night means that awards voters this year are interested in political themes, which would lead somewhat circuitously to "Babel" as the most politically relevant of the best picture nominees. Aw, never mind.
docs.abstract: Sunday was a big night for awards, but not for Oscar clarity.

headline.main: The Best Picture Picture Remains Fuzzy

docs.snippet: Robert Duval, actor, tango dancer and "Apocalypto" fan....
docs.lead_paragraph: The WGA Awards reception was hopping. Unlike past years where the show was a stuffy affair with a sit-down dinner at a ritzy hotel, this year the celebrities -- mainly television people and therefore b-list -- did their photo ops and then mingled with the crowds.
docs.abstract: Robert Duval, actor, tango dancer and "Apocalypto" fan.

docs.snippet: The Bagger's employer does something right....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger is fashion illiterate and doesn't go for glam shots, but if you'll forgive a little link-rolling, his corporate brothers and sisters at The New York Times magazine came up with a pretty amazing set of portraits of this year's the Oscar contenders, including some nicely thrown curve balls. Cooler still is a film by Jake Paltrow -- he's related to some actress, but the Bagger can't think of which one off the top of his head -- that consists of great talents talking about what they watched on screen before they began to live there. Who knew Cate Blanchett was a horror freak?
docs.abstract: The Bagger's employer does something right.

docs.snippet: The British billionaire Richard Branson and Al Gore, the former vice president, on Friday announced a $25 million prize to meet possibly the biggest challenge faced by humankind: to reduce the planet's warming gases that have collected in the atmo...
docs.lead_paragraph: The British billionaire Richard Branson and Al Gore, the former vice president, on Friday announced a $25 million prize to meet possibly the biggest challenge faced by humankind: to reduce the planet's warming gases that have collected in the atmosphere since the dawn of the Industrial Revolution. "We are now facing a planetary emergency," said Mr. Gore, the author of the book "An Inconvenient Truth," which formed the basis for an Oscar-nominated documentary film about global warming.
